creditline: The Lloyd E. Cotsen, Class of 1950, Eskimo Bone and Ivory Carving Collection

texts.textentryhtml: This unusual figure represents a male with pronounced genitalia and emerging breasts. Among Siberian Chukchi, transgender male shamans were believed to be the most powerful. They were commanded by the ke’let (spirits, sometimes female) to shed all male pursuits and sexual manners at an early age when shamanistic inspiration first manifested itself. Canadian Inuit myth reveals that a transgender shaman created all women. This was directly associated with his ability to straddle the procreative nature of the sexes. A groove, perhaps representing a charm belt, encircles the waist. The shoulder/breast design is typically Punuk in style and could represent beads, tattoos, or clothing decoration.

bibliography.boilertext: "Acquisitions of the Art Museum 1997," in "A Window into Collecting American Folk Art: The Edward Duff Balken Collection at Princeton," special issue, Record of the Art Museum, Princeton University 57, no. 1/2 (1998): p. 164-208.

bibliography.citation: Ralph T. Coe, Sacred Circles: Two Thousand Years of North American Indian Art (London: Hayward Gallery, 1976)., cat. no. 208 (illus.)
